awd_titl_txt: Modeling Glacial Lake Washburn - Insight into the LGM
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Project Description

Geologic field evidence of ancient lake level fluctuations in coastal Taylor Valley in the McMurdo Dry Valleys of Antarctica has been related to advances (higher lake levels) and retreats (lower lake levels) of the Ross Ice Sheet into the valley mouth during and since the last Glacial Maximum (24,000 to 13,000 years ago).  The ancient lake record provides some of the most complete terrestrial geologic evidence of inferred Antarctic ice-sheet changes at the height of the most recent bipolar glaciation.  Different interpretations of geologic deposits have led to two alternate hypotheses about how far inland the Ross Ice Sheet advanced to produce high lake levels during the Last Glacial Maximum. One hypothesis suggests that limited ice advances into the valley were associated with larger lakes, whereas the alternative suggests that more extensive ice advances were associated with much smaller lakes (by five times).  The local extent of ice advances has implications for the overall size of the Ross Ice Sheet and its impact on sea level.  This project will resolve the different interpretations by modeling the environmental conditions under which different sized lakes would form, with the hypothesis that one of the lake sizes would be more likely to occur.  In addition, the team will discover the environmental conditions that allow large lakes to form and be maintained when average air temperatures were much colder than today, an observation not supported by modern observations. 

Technical Project Description

A geomorphic record of lake level change in the McMurdo Dry Valleys will be used to infer environmental conditions during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) providing a climatic record over an 11,000-year period from 24,000 to about 13,000 years before present. Notable events during this period include the termination of the LGM global sea level low-stand, subsequent rapidly rising sea levels, and two episodes of abrupt sea level rise including meltwater pulse 1A. Specifically, the project will model lake level changes of Glacial Lake Washburn in Taylor Valley, the best documented paleo-lake in the region. Its level changed radically (100s m) over millennial time scales providing a strong signal of environmental change. Established energy balance models developed for the current climate and glaciological setting in Taylor Valley will be adapted to LGM conditions to model paleo-lake levels using estimated paleo-environmental conditions that include an atmosphere known to be cooler by -4 to -8 degrees Celsius. To define the range (uncertainty) of plausible environmental conditions that result in the same lake level a Monte Carlo-style approach is adopted. The results will provide a new perspective on past Antarctic climate and contribute to the debate on Antarctic sources to sea level rise.  The project will provide training for a Ph.D. student.

por.por_cntn:
Taylor Valley, Antarctica, is a polar desert composed of gravelly soils, a patchwork of ice-covered lakes and ponds, and glaciers descending from the surrounding mountains. Summers warm sufficiently to melt the glacier ice supplying streams that flow over the valley floor to the lakes. Along the valley walls is evidence of past shorelines much higher than today. This evidence is small horizontal ridges that ring the valley. Our thought was if we can model the changes in current lake levels, we can use it to model past lake level changes by changing the weather input data and we would have an understanding of the past climate in this region of Antarctica. The more we know about past climate the better we can anticipate future changes.

The model is composed of two parts. The first part predicts how much glacial meltwater is generated by the summer weather. Obviously, warmer the weather more meltwater, but the wind is cool, suppressing melt. So, these and other variables make predicting glacial melt challenging. The second part is lake level change. Water to the lakes comes from the glacial melt, there is no rain in Taylor Valley and what little snow falls usually evaporates before it can form streams. Because the lakes are in closed basins with no outlet (like the Great Salt Lake, UT), the only loss is through evaporation of the ice surface. Our model worked very well using modern weather input to accurately predict lake level changes.

The model showed us that meltwater production was very sensitive to small changes in environmental conditions. Unlike in the USA, the glaciers barely melt in Taylor Valley, so small changes in energy available to the glacier results in big changes in melt. We also learned about environmental conditions in Taylor Valley. We had thought the atmosphere was pretty much the same, but the modeling showed us that it is probably much more humid in one part of the valley. Also, there might be significant shallow groundwater moving in other part of the valley. Together these insights help understand how this valley operates and may influence local biology. Finally, the model suggested that the lakes are out of balance with the climate. The lakes have been rising since measurements began 20 years ago and our model can predict those changes. So it must be that the climate was colder and the lake levels were lower sometime in the past. Assuming current climate conditions stay the same, the lakes will continue to rise for the next few hundred years before water input from the glaciers matches the water loss by evaporation. The valley gets wider with elevation and deeper lakes have a greater surface area and more evaporative water loss.

Two immediately useful applications of our model results include,

a. Predictions of lake level rise will help the contractors in Antarctica schedule moving the fixed camps in Taylor Valley. All those camps are near the lakes.

b. Our results will be used by the biologists who study biological processes in this extreme environment and help answer questions about how can life survive here and what does that imply for life on other planets?

We used the model to determine climate conditions thousands of years ago based on evidence of past lake levels found on the valley walls. We can’t reliably predict the lake levels for past lakes if the elevation difference between them is small. That results from the sensitivity of ice melt to changes in weather as described before, a little change in air temperature or wind speed one way or the other results in big changes in glacier meltwater. However, for big differences in lake levels, and those are our priority, the differences in weather are big too, so the results are more reliable. The results about past lake levels will be finalized soon.
